skillsText2: Discover my current skills for <bold className='strokeme text-royalAmethyst'>web development</bold>. I believe I can do anything that other people can with all the skills presented here. While I don't know everything, I'm always learning and improving so I can deliver a better experience to all. <bold className='text-white75'>|</bold> <bold className='text-primaryBlue strokeme'>*Click on a card to reveal more information about each skill.</bold>

skillsData.name: JavaScript
skillsData.description: JavaScript is a versatile scripting language commonly used to create dynamic and interactive web pages. With its widespread adoption, it's an essential skill for front-end and back-end development.
skillsData.extraNote: I've utilized JavaScript on a few Online Student Projects, implementing common features like Hamburger Menus, Image Slideshows, Dropdowns, and Modals. Although, it's nothing special that I don't do already on React / Nextjs. Anyway, I can always come back to it to make new projects and learn a bit more.

skillsData.name: CSS / SASS / SCSS
skillsData.description: CSS (Cascading Style Sheets) is the language used to style HTML documents. It controls the layout and appearance of web pages, allowing developers to create visually appealing and responsive designs.

skillsData.name: Node.js
skillsData.description: Node.js is a server-side JavaScript runtime that allows developers to build scalable and efficient network applications. It's widely used for creating web servers and handling asynchronous tasks.
skillsData.extraNote: I've applied Node.js in an online student project while concurrently learning React. The project focused on a social website, featuring user registration, login, post creation, editing, deletion, likes, comments, user profiles, and profile editing. Additional features included an AuthGuard, user validation, and more. Regrettably, the project remained incomplete due to its nature as an online learning exercise. I thought about completing it by strengthening the AuthGuard, implementing confirmation emails and phone numbers, refining post likes with algorithms, adding post filters, improving the overall design, enabling comment replies, incorporating notifications, friend lists, and other many, many features so it could be ready for production in a real-world scenario. However, the amount of work for creating a fully-fledged social media site completely alone felt like it would require a way too extreme amount of time invested in it, so I discarded the idea after doing it for a while.

skillsData.name: HTML
skillsData.description: HTML (Hypertext Markup Language) is the foundation of web development. It structures content on the web, defining the elements that make up a webpage, such as headings, paragraphs, and images.

skillsData.name: Next.js
skillsData.description: Next.js is a React framework that simplifies the process of building server-side rendered and statically generated React applications. It enhances the performance and SEO of web applications.
skillsData.extraNote: So far, my favorite. It's straightforward and kind of does some heavy lifting for you. As someone who likes to make websites that are user-friendly for everyone, having an easy-to-use programming language that makes things simpler for developers is definitely a huge plus for me, and I can definitely appreciate the effort put into it.

skillsData.name: React / React + Typescript
skillsData.description: React is a JavaScript library for building user interfaces. It allows developers to create reusable components, making it efficient to build and maintain complex web applications.

skillsData.name: Bootstrap
skillsData.description: Bootstrap is a popular CSS framework that streamlines the process of designing responsive and visually appealing websites. It provides a set of pre-designed components and styles.

skillsData.name: Figma
skillsData.description: Figma is a collaborative design tool that allows designers to create, share, and collaborate on user interfaces in real-time. It's widely used for designing web and mobile applications.

skillsData.name: Tailwind CSS
skillsData.description: Tailwind CSS is a utility-first CSS framework that simplifies the process of styling web applications. It provides low-level utility classes to build designs quickly and maintainably.
skillsData.extraNote: When I heard about the concept Bootstrap had to offer, this is exactly what I thought it would be. Using normal CSS/SASS/SCSS and even Bootstrap honestly feels like a waste when you have Tailwind CSS around. I 100% recommend it to all Developers out there.

skillsData.name: WordPress
skillsData.description: WordPress is a content management system (CMS) that powers a significant portion of the web. It's used for building websites and blogs, offering a user-friendly interface and extensive plugin support.
skillsData.extraNote: Like Strapi, I've solely used WordPress as a Headless CMS. Unfortunately, I haven't gone too deeply into WordPress, but I'm very inclined to explore it further in the future. The plugins it has to offer might make it a better choice than Strapi, and it may as well be less limiting and offer more freedom at the cost of possible being a bit tougher to use and manage as a Developer than Strapi was.

skillsData.name: Firebase
skillsData.description: Firebase is a mobile and web application development platform provided by Google. It offers a suite of cloud services, including authentication, real-time databases, and hosting, simplifying backend development.
skillsData.extraNote: I used it as a database for a social website in an online student project, storing photos of posts, profile pictures, user accounts, and more. I didn't do anything particularly special with it, and I believe similar results could be achieved with any other database without issues.

skillsData.name: Strapi
skillsData.description: Strapi is an open-source headless CMS that enables developers to build powerful APIs quickly. It's flexible, customizable, and suitable for creating content-rich applications.
skillsData.extraNote: I use Strapi as a content management for my Doggy Daycare project. From my perspective, Strapi felt more accessible and visually modern compared to WordPress when I started, as it was literally made to be a Headless CMS. However, as I explored further, the limitations in terms of plugins and features made me seriously question whether WordPress might have offered superior customization as a Headless CMS for the client's content. Honestly, I still have yet to try WordPress in depth to be able to tell if that was really the case.

skillsData.name: Other
skillsData.description: The "Other" category represents my openness to learning new skills and technologies. Even if I haven't encountered a specific language or tool yet, I believe I can adapt and acquire the necessary knowledge to use it for production if I have a bit of time to spend learning it.

projectsText3: While I've done various <bold className='text-royalAmethyst font-bold strokeme'>projects for learning only</bold>, this portfolio exclusively features my <bold className='text-royalAmethyst font-bold strokeme'>comprehensive projects—distinct from mere incomplete learning exercises</bold>. Representing my personal work in design and code, these projects not only display my style but also integrate many skills I have learned soo far.

projectsData.name: Doggy Daycare
projectsData.description: A project about a fictional Doggy Daycare. Although the Name isn't very creative, the Site was made only with the goal of self-improvement. It served as a platform to mainly enhance my design skills, and utilize a popular CMS tool such as Strapi and WordPress, as I'm quite a fan of the Idea of what a CMS can do. The project also aimed at refining my coding proficiency in Next.js, implementing accessibility features, and a few more.
projectsData.descriptionFeatures: Strapi CMS, Interactive Map, Automatic Email, Accessibility Integration, Loading Screen & Skeleton Loading.

technologiesUsed.name: Next.js
technologiesUsed.reasonWhy: Next.js was chosen for its efficiency in building React applications and its default dynamic routes & config, allowing the Project to progress faster without needing too many custom configurations like custom Routes.

technologiesUsed.name: Tailwind CSS
technologiesUsed.reasonWhy: Tailwind CSS was selected to streamline the styling process with its utility-first approach, ensuring a clean and maintainable codebase. It made styling the website be extremely fast. I honestly can't stress enough about how useful it was.

technologiesUsed.name: Strapi
technologiesUsed.reasonWhy: Strapi served as the headless CMS to manage content, providing flexibility and ease of use, allowing for efficient content updates. Although, I wouldn't recommend it too much, as at least for me, I felt like quite a bit of features were lacking.

technologiesUsed.name: Figma
technologiesUsed.reasonWhy: Figma was the main design tool; its plugins and features helped a lot, ensuring a cohesive and visually appealing user interface.

technologiesUsed.name: CSS
technologiesUsed.reasonWhy: While Tailwind CSS was the primary styling tool, custom CSS was utilized for specific design elements, providing a better visual experience.

challenges.challengeDescription: Creating the reservation form had its challenges. While the main functions worked well—sending data to Strapi and triggering email notifications—the details of form validation and user experience needed improvement. Ensuring accessibility is uncertain without real users for testing, and as a learning project, I didn't want to inconvenience users solely for testing and learning purposes.
challenges.solutionText: To address these challenges, I refined the form's visual cues for better feedback and extensively tested it with NVDA Screen Reader. I also consulted online guides on form accessibility. However, determining the form's success remains challenging without real-world user interaction. Continuous improvement is completely possible and essential if the website was gonna be accessible to the public as a non-fictional project.

challenges.challengeDescription: Working with Strapi for content management was straightforward, but certain limitations posed challenges. Strapi lacked features like adding descriptions or placeholders to custom fields, making it challenging for admins to understand their functions. Customizing the Strapi interface was restricted, resulting in some field pages appearing disorganized. Issues with JSON fields could lead to content display problems if the Admin writes anything in the wrong way on it, as there were no restrictions about what you can type. The absence of user feedback made it difficult to pinpoint improvements, especially when Strapi provided limited flexibility for admin convenience.
challenges.solutionText: To address these challenges, I created tutorial videos showing each field's functionality. You can find the project on my GitHub repository, along with videos on setup, image scaling for space-saving, backups, and deployment. If you are testing it and you have any questions or need clarification, feel free to reach out.
